messageBody:
> I am in charge of getting a test
> framework written for an application with over 200K lines of code that does
> not have a single test case yet. Yikes! It is very confusing about how to
> start and how to set up an application level test suite that will touch all
> the classes.


- Forget about strictly applying XP and test-first concept. Don't write
tests for a class if you don't need to.
- Start from the top. I imagine that your application is somewhat
running: First write some general tests that exercise the application or
use reports from your QA. Once you have discovered a class with
potential bugs, try to test your class. If you can't write tests, you
may have to refactor the class (and write tests before refactoring)
- maybe JUnit is too "unit-centered" to help you. Have a look at
commercial products (TestMentor by SylverMark or others): they may
enable you to faster cover your application with several testing methods
(and not only unit testing).
- by analysing your code and report some metrics (complexity,
inheritence, coupling...), you may be able to guess the classes that are
the mose likely to be bugged (have a look at JDepend from Mike Clark)

These are only guesses since I never faced a similar situation (in Java)
but it would be _really_ interesting to have some kind of "How to
survive a not tested project" article.

-Vladimir
